column4: what do you mean under "root maintainance"? a recovery mode of Ubuntu?
Ok, but do you have net connection? What kind of errors prevent Ubuntu from accomplishing the boot process?
it used to get stuck on "starting ntp server ntpd" under the  nework configuration... now it gets stuck on network configuration because i disinstalled the ntp

hm... Well, if all you need is configure network connection from the recovery mode, you just need to put in proper config in /etc/network/interfaces and /etc/resolv.conf files, and then run '/etc/init.d/networking restart' to apply the changes
:S:S any online guide on how to do that?
read only the "Defining physical interfaces such as eth0" section here: http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/setting-up-an-network-interfaces-file/
thanks,i wiill let you know how it goes
and as for /etc/resolv.conf, you have to put DNS servers addresses there. The format is as follows: "nameserver 208.67.222.222", one nameserver per line
Oh, and don't touch the "lo" interface in /etc/network/interfaces... it may have unexpected results. Better yet, backup both files before changing (I should add this advice to my signature)
so, did you manage to get the connection?

managed to setup internet connection to repair damaged packets,but when i restart(after having reinstalled ntp) i get blocked on "configuring network interfaces". If i skip that setup (with ctrl+alt+canc) the boot goes ahead but doesn't start the logon screen :S
I guess I know what's the problem
you'll be saving my life. i've got two university exams on monday and tuesday.. :S
Please, check that you have following lines in your /etc/network/interfaces: "auto lo", "iface lo inet loopback", and the line "127.0.0.1 localhost" in /etc/hosts
ok,anything else in case?? because i have to reboot my laptop. i have a dual boot
well, where does your system freeze? After logging in, right?
no,it freezes during boot,at half way of the orange bar

hm, then you can 1). press Ctrl+Alt+F8 and possibly see any error messages, or 2). press Ctrl+Alt+F1 to get access to console and log in. There you may try to look what kind of error messages the system spits out. You can use 'dmesg' program for it like in 'dmesg | less', or just go to /var/log/, and try to look there for appropriate log files.
In order to get back to GUI, press Ctrl+Alt+F7
